Title: Linking forum posts -medicalneuro-002-1-T1.1
Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
In what hemisphere would one find the 'omega sign' behind the central sulcus? Is it on the side of the 'dominant' hand of the brain? I seem to notice an omega sign in the left hemisphere in the Sylvius 4 Online Atlas (Surface Anatomy > Photograph Atlas > Sulci and Fissures; then select Lateral Left, third from the top; and then select Lateral Right, fifth from the top). Specifically, is the left central sulcus always 'more straight' than the right central sulcus, as Dr. White explained in his favorite places of the brain? Thanks in advance!
Upvotes:
0
It's usually on the opposite hemisphere from the dominant hand. For example I'm right-handed and I have that sign of omega shape on the left hemisphere of my brain. But that's not always the case. Einstein was right-handed and he had that shape on his right hemisphere. It was probably because he was a long time violinist. See this very interesting article on Einstein's brain .

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Thanks for your interest in this issue. Research that Dale Purves and I began in the mid-90s and continued by several other research groups suggests that indeed there is a size asymmetry in the 'omega' region of the central sulcus and/or the white matter pathways that arise from this region, with the left side being larger than right side in right handers (most of us). Unfortunately, I do not know the handedness of the person from whom the brain in this video was obtained, but odds are that it is from a right-handed individual. So it seems that in the ongoing debate about 'bigger being better', handedness (and eyedness) may be reflected in an increased volume of neural tissue dedicated to the body part expressing greater skill. But I remain quite cautious in applying the 'bigger is better' dictum to other kinds of neural circuits where function is much less circumscribed. One last note on this post ... both hemispheres have something like an 'omega' shape in the central sulcus where the walls of the precentral and postcentral gyrus interdigitate. As this is where the contralateral hand is represented in the somatic sensorimotor cortex, it appears that this interdigitation is deeper and larger in the hemisphere that represents the preferred hand.

Actually, projection neurons have longer distances. An interneuron is typically a short neuron that connects other neurons together in a circuit. It is also typically between a sensory neuron and a motor neuron in along a particular circuit. An example might be the knee-jerk reflex. The hammer hits the patellar ligament causing sensory information to flow to the spinal cord. This neuron synapses with a motor neuron that services the quad muscles in the leg to cause contraction. ... But, the sensory neuron ALSO connects to an interneuron that then synapses with the motor neurons of the hamstring ceasing or inhibiting contraction of the back-of-the-leg muscles allowing the leg to extend without tearing or straining the hamstrings. Check out this image: http://faculty.pasadena.edu/dkwon/PNS%20and%20propioception/peripheral%20nervous%20system%20and%20propioception_files/images/image48.png

Thanks for the clarifying posts! I believe the confusion came up when I used the 'classic' definition of interneuron as a neuron whose projections are limited to the CNS. I do believe that I made it clear that most contemporary neuroscientists consider interneurons to be neurons with short axons that are distributed locally, rather than projecting long distances within the CNS. Which types of cells and which connections within and between layers are excitatory and which inhibitory? Common wisdom in the bit of modelling I've done was that inhibitory connections are more uniformly and more broadly spread (within local populations), while excitatory connections are confined within and between separate groups of neurons. Is this true, and would it mean that inhibitory connections spread horizontally (to adjacent microcircuits) more than excitatory connections? Also, very importantly: do inputs from the thalamus target both excitatory and inhibitory neurons directly? Thank you very much to anyone who might have answers.

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The general case seems to be that excitatory connections extend for greater distance (up to 6 mm) within the cortical circuit than do inhibitory connections (up to 2 mm), and that these long-ranging connections (in the 2-6 mm range) tend to make clustered, connections on columns of neurons within the same cortical area that share similar response properties. Excitatory neurons also give rise to local connections (<2 mm) that are typically portrayed as being less specific and less clustered. However, my reading of the literature and some of my own unpublished results indicate that even these local connections might have a surprising degree of specificity to them. The inhibitory neurons are quite a heterogeneous collections of neurons. There are certainly some that appear to give rise to local, nonspecific connections. But there may be some types of inhibitory interneurons that actually give rise to quite specific connections. This remains an area of current controversy among those investigators with the methods to really sort this out; and there may be species differences that make consensus more elusive. Given your modeling background, you may recognize that the idea of long-ranging excitatory connections is a problem for typical 'Mexican hat' integration functions. This may indeed be a problem, or the problem may be resolved by local inhibitory interneurons mediating the impact of long-ranging excitatory connections. The cortex is truly a wonderful and mysterious place to lose oneself in the details!

Description: The workers will be presented with posts from a forum thread where instructors of a course have replied to student posts. The worker is required to: identify the student post(s) that the instructor’s reply addresses. Instructor's reply post is highlighted
Keywords: tagging, categorization, discussion forum, forum threads, mooc
Input.posts:
Which types of cells and which connections within and between layers are excitatory and which inhibitory? Common wisdom in the bit of modelling I've done was that inhibitory connections are more uniformly and more broadly spread (within local populations), while excitatory connections are confined within and between separate groups of neurons. Is this true, and would it mean that inhibitory connections spread horizontally (to adjacent microcircuits) more than excitatory connections? Also, very importantly: do inputs from the thalamus target both excitatory and inhibitory neurons directly? Thank you very much to anyone who might have answers.
Upvotes:
0
Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
The general case seems to be that excitatory connections extend for greater distance (up to 6 mm) within the cortical circuit than do inhibitory connections (up to 2 mm), and that these long-ranging connections (in the 2-6 mm range) tend to make clustered, connections on columns of neurons within the same cortical area that share similar response properties. Excitatory neurons also give rise to local connections (<2 mm) that are typically portrayed as being less specific and less clustered. However, my reading of the literature and some of my own unpublished results indicate that even these local connections might have a surprising degree of specificity to them. The inhibitory neurons are quite a heterogeneous collections of neurons. There are certainly some that appear to give rise to local, nonspecific connections. But there may be some types of inhibitory interneurons that actually give rise to quite specific connections. This remains an area of current controversy among those investigators with the methods to really sort this out; and there may be species differences that make consensus more elusive. Given your modeling background, you may recognize that the idea of long-ranging excitatory connections is a problem for typical 'Mexican hat' integration functions. This may indeed be a problem, or the problem may be resolved by local inhibitory interneurons mediating the impact of long-ranging excitatory connections. The cortex is truly a wonderful and mysterious place to lose oneself in the details!

Input.inst_post:
Instructor's Post
Ana, good and detailed questions! There are robust projections from cortical areas to the thalamic divisions that provide feedforward input, and connections to higher order thalamic divisions that participate in circuits that loop through the thalamus and cortex, and back again. Numerous other thalamic structures, including the intralaminar nuclei, also project to the prefrontal cortex, but with weaker connections.
